paper_name: FLOOD: A Flexible Invariant Learning Framework for Out-of-Distribution Generalization on Graphs
method_summary: FLOOD is a novel framework designed for out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization on graphs. It integrates two key components: invariant learning and bootstrapped learning. The invariant learning part constructs diverse training environments through graph data augmentation, enabling the model to learn invariant representations by capturing consistent graph patterns amidst potential distributions shifts. In contrast, the bootstrapped learning component employs a shared graph encoder trained in a self-supervised manner, which can be refined flexibly during the testing phase, allowing adaptation to the target distribution. This dual approach aims to enhance the model's robustness to distributional variations between training and testing datasets.
experiment_summary: Extensive experiments evaluate the effectiveness of FLOOD across both transductive and inductive graph OOD settings. The results demonstrate that FLOOD consistently outperforms existing methods in terms of generalization capabilities, illustrating the advantages of its flexible adaptation strategies during the test phase. The experiments focus on various datasets and benchmark tasks to validate the benefits of integrating invariant and bootstrapped learning approaches.
